Graphical abstract Highlights ► New oxo-vanadium(IV) complexes with pyrazole or tris(pyrazolyl)ethanol ligands. ► Immobilization of those V complexes on a polydimethylsiloxane membrane. ► Homogeneous or supported V complexes catalyze cyclohexane oxidation. The oxovanadium(IV) complexes [VO(acac)2(Hpz)]·HC(pz)3 1·HC(pz)3 (acac=acetylacetonate, Hpz=pyrazole, pz=pyrazolyl) and [VOCl2{HOCH2C(pz)3}] 2 were obtained from reaction of [VO(acac)2] with hydrotris(1-pyrazolyl)methane or of VCl3with 2,2,2-tris(1-pyrazolyl)ethanol. The compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, Far-IR and EPR spectroscopies, FAB or ESI mass-spectrometry and, for 1, by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 1 and 2 exhibit catalytic activity for the oxidation of cyclohexane to the cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone mixture in homogeneous system (TONs up to 1100) under mild conditions (NCMe, 24h, room temperature) using benzoyl peroxide (BPO), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), m-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (mCPBA), hydrogen peroxide or the urea-hydrogen peroxide adduct (UHP) as oxidants. 1 and 2 were also immobilized on a polydimethylsiloxane membrane (1-PDMS or 2-PDMS) and the systems acted as supported catalysts for the cyclohexane oxidation using the above oxidants (TONs up to 620). The best results were obtained with mCPBA or BPO as oxidant. The effects of various parameters, such as the amount of catalyst, nitric acid, reaction time, type of oxidant and oxidant-to-catalyst molar ratio, were investigated, for both homogeneous and supported systems. Keywords Cyclohexane C-scorpionates Vanadium Homogeneous catalysis Oxidation Crystal structure Supported catalysis 1 Introduction Functionalization reactions of saturated hydrocarbons, in particular oxidations, provide rather promising methods towards the use of such unreactive compounds as raw materials for organic synthesis [1–4]. An example with industrial significance concerns the oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone that are important reagents for the production of adipic acid and caprolactam used for the manufacture of nylon. The industrial process uses a homogeneous cobalt species as catalyst and dioxygen as oxidant, at a considerably high temperature (150°C), forming the oxidation products in a low yield to achieve a good selectivity [2], and the need to search for more active systems under milder reaction conditions has been recognized [2,3]. The coordination chemistry of vanadium, in particular with biological significance, is experiencing a noticeable development [5] and during the last few years a number of V complexes has been applied as catalysts or catalyst precursors for oxidation of alkanes [1a–1c,3,5,6]. Vanadium complexes with N,O- or O,O-ligands act as remarkably active catalysts or catalyst precursors for a variety of alkane functionalization reactions under mild conditions, including their oxygenation or carboxylation [6]. The most active ones include Amavadin, an intriguing natural VIV complex, [V{ON(CH(CH3)COO)2}2]2− [ON(CH(CH3)COO)2 =basic form of 2,2′-(hydroxyimino)dipropionic acid (HIDPA)3−] [6d,7] present in Amanita muscaria fungi, its model [V{ON(CH2COO)2}2]2− [ON(CH2COO)2 =basic form of 2,2′-(hydroxyimino)diacetic acid (HIDA)3−], the vanadium(V) triethanolaminate derivative [VO{N(CH2CH2O)3}] [7], and the system based on vanadate and 2-pyrazinecarboxylic acid [3f,6g,8]. They are followed by dioxovanadium(V) complexes bearing C- or B-scorpionate ligands [6k]. The catalytic processes can involve liquid biphasic systems or supported catalysts [9] and proceed, at least in part, via radical mechanisms in which the VIV/VV redox interconversion conceivably plays an important role. The major advantage of heterogeneous catalysts is the ease of separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture [2,6l,9,10], minimizing the additional work-up procedures which often can be expensive and lead to the generation of toxic waste. Moreover, the support structure and surface characteristics can benefit the reaction, e.g., by controlling the orientation of the substrate and reagents and thus the reaction selectivity or by helping to activate them [2,3,9]. The exponential growth in the use of polymer-supported methodology attests the advantages offered by such solid phase strategies. Mechanical resistance, swelling, chemical stabilities and porosity are some of the useful poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) membrane properties. This polymer also bears flexible siloxane chains which provide a fast mass transfer and create a hydrophobic environment around the metal active site, thus leading to the control of reactants sorption by preferential uptake of apolar molecules such as alkane and alkenes [11,12]. It has been successfully applied to the immobilization of oxygenation catalysts, such as phthalocyanines [13,14] or Mn(salen) [15], by physical occlusion and van der Waals forces. Hybrid membranes based on poly(dimethylsiloxane) and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PDMS/PVA) in a triphasic system, where the membrane is located in the interface between the apolar (organic substrate) and aqueous (containing the oxidant) phases [16], have also been used. Following our interest in the oxidation reactions of alkanes catalyzed by various vanadium compounds [6], the present work aims to extend these studies to explore the application of the new complexes [VO(acac)2(Hpz)] 1 and [VOCl2{HOCH2C(pz)3}] 2, under both homogeneous and heterogeneous (immobilized on a PDMS based membrane) conditions for the cyclohexane oxidation. The role of the support in the reactivity of these complexes and the influence of various parameters, such as type of oxidants, time, additives and amount of catalyst, are investigated and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 General materials and procedures Vanadium(III) chloride (Acros), vanadium(IV) acetylacetonate (Aldrich), cyclohexane (Merck), acetonitrile (Riedel-de-Haën), pentane (Riedel-de-Haën), tetrahydrofurane (Riedel-de-Haën), methanol (Lab-Scan), hydrogen peroxide (30%) (H2O2) (Fluka), benzoyl peroxide (BPO) (Fluka), ter-butyl hydroperoxide (70%) (TBHP) (Aldrich), m-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (77%) (mCPBA) (Aldrich), urea hydrogen peroxide adduct (97%) (UHP) (Alfa Aesar), nitric acid (65%) (Riedel-de-Haën), cycloheptanone (Riedel-de-Haën), diethyl ether (Riedel-de-Haën), poly(dimethylsiloxane) hydroxyl terminated (Aldrich), tetraethyl orthosilicate (99%) (TEOS) (Aldrich) and dibutyltin dilaurate (95%) (Aldrich) were used as received from the supplier. Hydrotris(1-pyrazolyl)methane, HC(pz)3, and 2,2,2-tris(l-pyrazolyl)ethanol, HOCH2C(pz)3, were obtained according to published methods [17]. Infrared spectra (4000–400cm−1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX instrument, in KBr pellets; wavenumbers are in cm−1; abbreviations: vs, very strong; s, strong; m, medium; w, weak. Far infrared spectra (400–200cm−1) were recorded on a Vertex 70 spectrophotometer, in polyethylene pellets. ESI+/ESI−mass spectra were obtained on a VARIAN 500-MS LC ion trap mass spectrometer (solvent: dimethylsulfoxide; flow: 20μL/min; needle spray voltage: ±5kV, capillarity voltage: ±100V; nebulizer gas (N2): 35psi; drying gas (N2): 10psi; drying gas temperature (N2): 350°C). EPR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ESP 300E X-band spectrophotometer equipped with an ER 4111 VT variable-temperature unit. The C, H, N elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico. Gas chromatographic (GC) measurements were carried out using a FISONS Instruments GC 8000 series gas chromatograph with a FID detector and a capillary column (DB-WAX, column length: 30m; internal diameter: 0.32mm). The temperature of injection was 240°C. The initial temperature was maintained at 100°C for 1min, then raised 10°C/min to 180°C. Helium was used as the carrier gas. GC–MS was performed using a Clarus 600 Perkin Elmer. The ionization voltage was 70eV. Gas chromatography was conducted in the temperature-programming mode, using a SGE BPX5 column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). Reaction products were identified by comparison of their retention times with known reference compounds, and by comparing their mass spectra to fragmentation patterns obtained from the NIST spectral library stored in the computer software of the mass spectrometer. 2.1.1 X-ray structure determinations The X-ray quality single crystal of complex 1 was immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop and measured at a temperature of 150K. Intensity data were collected on a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ 0.71073). Data were collected using omega scans of 0.5° per frame and a full sphere of data was obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT [18] on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS [18]. The structure was solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS-97 package [19a] and refined with SHELXL-97 [19b]. Calculations were performed using the WinGX System – Version 1.80.03 [20]. All hydrogen atoms were inserted in calculated positions. Least square refinement with anisotropic thermal motion parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic for the remaining atoms gave R1=0. 0324 [I >2σ(I); R1=0.0391 (all data)]. The maximum and minimum peaks in the final difference electron density map are of 0.289 and −0.332. CCDC 882590 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. 2.2 Synthesis and characterization of new complexes 2.2.1 [VO(acac)2(Hpz)]·HC(pz)3 1·HC(pz)3 To a solution of [VO(acac)2] (0.20g, 0.75mmol) in MeOH (25.0mL) an equimolar amount of HC(pz)3 (0.16g, 0.75mmol) in MeOH (10.0mL) was added, with constant stirring and in air. The resulting green solution was left stirring overnight in air and then concentrated under vacuum. Upon addition of Et2O, a green solid precipitated which was collected by filtration, washed with Et2O and dried in vacuo (0.19g, 48% yield). 1·HC(pz)3 is soluble in ethanol (S25°C ≈3.0mg/mL) and acetone. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1535 and 1419 [s, ν(CC) and ν(NC), Hpz], 990 [s, ν(VO)]. ESI+: m/z 333 ([M]+), 266 ([M−pz]+). EPR (MeOH, r.t.): a =101.9G, g =1.9834. Anal. Calc. for VO5C23H28N8: C, 50.5; H, 5.2; N, 20.5%. Found: C, 51.1; H, 5.8; N, 20.8%. 2.2.2 [VOCl2{HOCH2C(pz)3}] 2 To a solution of vanadium trichloride (0.20g, 1.27mmol) in THF (15.0mL) an equimolar quantity of HOCH2C(pz)3 (0.31g, 1.27mmol) in THF (10.0mL) was added, with constant stirring in air. The resulting grey solution was left stirring overnight and then concentrated under vacuum. Upon addition of Et2O, a grey solid precipitated which was collected by filtration, washed with Et2O and dried in vacuo (0.25g, 51% yield). 2 is soluble in water (S25°C ≈4.9mg/mL), MeOH, NCMe, DMSO and DMF. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3406 [s, ν(OH), HOCH2C(pz)3], 1622 and 1520 [s, ν(NC), (NN), HOCH2C(pz)3], 970 [m, ν(VO)], 388 and 347 [ν(VCl)]. EPR (DMSO, r.t.): a =101.8G, g =1.9999. ESI+: m/z 346 ([M−Cl]+), 314 ([M−pz]+). Anal. Calc. for VO2Cl2C11H12N6: C, 34.6; H, 3.2; N, 22.0%. Found: C, 34.1; H, 3.1; N, 21.4%. 2.3 Heterogeneous system 2.3.1 Preparation of PDMS membranes PDMS polymer (83.5wt.%) was dissolved in isopropanol and then the crosslinking agent (TEOS – 16.2wt.%) and catalyst (dibutyltin dilaurate – 0.01wt.%) were added to the polymer solution. This mixture was heated in an oil bath at 40°C and the hydrolysis and condensation reactions between TEOS and PDMS allowed proceeding for 30min. A DMSO solution of the vanadium complex (4.18mmolL−1) was then added, and the loading level of the immobilized vanadium was measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) and shown to be ca. 0.29 or 0.20% (wt/wt) of the vanadium complex on the PDMS membrane (1-PDMS or 2-PDMS, respectively), corresponding to a catalyst loading of 5.3μmol (vanadium complex) per gram of polymer. The coated membranes were cured at room temperature for 5 days on Teflon™ Petri dishes to produce mechanically stable, crack-free self-supported films. 2.3.2 Sorption measurements For the sorption measurements, dried sheet-shaped 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS samples were immersed in acetonitrile under similar conditions as those of the reaction for the oxidants (mCPBA, BPO, UHP, TBHP or H2O2), i.e., at room temperature for 24h. Membrane swelling was monitored until the film had reached a constant weight. Samples were withdrawn from the solvent every now and then, and weighed after removal of the surface solvent by light blotting with a filter paper. The sorption of oxidants on the membrane was obtained by determining their swelling using the following expression [21]: Sorption ( mmol g − 1 ) = ( W 1 − W 2 ) W 1 × 1000 MW , where W 1 and W 2 stand for the membranes weights (g) in the wet and dry states, respectively, and MW is the molecular weight of the oxidant. 2.4 Catalytic activity studies 2.4.1 Homogeneous and heterogeneous systems In typical conditions the reaction mixtures were prepared as follows: 1 and 2 (3.65×10−5 mol), as a 0.018M stock solution in acetonitrile or immobilized on a polymeric membrane (1-PDMS or 2-PDMS), were diluted with NCMe until a total solution volume of 3.00mL, where after 6.00mmol of oxidant, HNO3 (0.08mL) and 5.00mmol of cyclohexane (0.54mL) were added (in this order) and the reaction solution was stirred for 24h, at the desired temperature (commonly room temperature) and normal pressure. In heterogeneous systems, in order to investigate the effect of the amount of catalyst (0.1–0.5μmol) and membrane sorption capability on the oxidation reaction, membrane pieces of different sizes, but with the same catalyst concentration, were used. For the products analysis, 90μL of cycloheptanone (internal standard) and 5.0mL of diethyl ether (to extract the substrate and the organic products from the reaction mixture) were added. The obtained mixture was stirred during 10min and then a sample (1μL) was taken from the organic phase and analyzed by GC by the internal standard method. Blank experiments confirmed that no cyclohexanol or cyclohexanone are formed without the metal catalyst. The amount of alkyl hydroperoxide (if formed) was estimated from the variations in the alcohol and ketone yields, determined by GC, analyses, upon addition of PPh3 to the final reaction solution, according to a method reported by Shul’pin [3b,8b,22,23]. The carbon radical trap [24] CBrCl3 was used in a stoichiometric amount relative to substrate (cyclohexane) and the oxygen radical trap Ph2NH was added in a stoichiometric amount relative to BPO. Eventual leaching from the membrane of the supported complexes was tested by performing the following experiment. 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS were mixed with acetonitrile and BPO under typical reaction conditions. After 6h of intensive stirring, the 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS membranes were removed, cyclohexane was added to the solution which was then stirred for 24h. Analyses of this solution by GC revealed no traces of the oxygenated products, thus excluding the hypothesis of a significant leaching of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and spectroscopic characterization of compounds 1 and 2 [VO(acac)2(Hpz)]·HC(pz)3 1·HC(pz)3 was obtained directly from vanadyl acetylacetonate in MeOH in the presence of HC(pz)3, whereas [VOCl2{HOCH2C(pz)3}] 2 was prepared from the reaction of vanadium(III) chloride with HOCH2C(pz)3 in THF. The latter appears to provide, to our knowledge, the first example of a vanadium(IV) complex bearing the tris(pyrazolyl)ethanol ligand. The formation of 1 involves the rupture of a C(sp 3)-N(pyrazolyl) bond in HC(pz)3. Such a type of behaviour had been shown for the vanadium complex [VO2(3,5-Me2Hpz)3][BF4] derived from reaction of [VO(OEt)3] with HC(3,5-Me2pz)3 [6k]. Other cases of metal-induced cleavage of such a type of bond have been reported, namely the CN bond rupture in HC(pz)3 or HC(3,5-Me2pz)3 by the benzoylhydrazido rhenium(V) chelate [ReCl2{η2-N,O-N2C(O)Ph}(PPh3)2] [25] or in bis(pyrazolyl)propane (CH3)2C(pz)2 by Pt(II) complexes [26,27], namely [PtCl2(RCN)2] (R=Me or Ph) or K2[PtCl4]. In all the reported cases, the way the cleavage reaction occurs has not been established. The complexes (Scheme 1 ) were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, Far-IR and EPR spectroscopies and, in the case of 1·HC(pz)3, by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The IR spectrum of 2 exhibits medium intensity bands at ca. 3406cm−1 assigned to the ν(OH) stretching mode of the ligated HOCH2C(pz)3. Moreover, 1 and 2 display ν(CC) and ν(CN) bands of their pyrazolyl or pyrazole groups at the normal [6e,27,28] range of 1622–1419cm−1. The ν(VO) values in 1 and 2 are comparable to those quoted for several oxovanadium(IV) complexes bearing the tris(pyrazolyl)borate ligand, such as [VOCl{HB(3,5-Me2pz)3}(Me2Hpz)] [29,30]. In 2, the presence of the chloro ligands is confirmed by the corresponding ν(VCl) bands in the 388–347cm−1 range. The EPR spectra of 1 and 2 show the expected 8-line pattern of a paramagnetic V(IV) monomeric species (51V, I =7/2) with typical values [31] of the g and a parameters. The FAB+-MS or ESI+ spectra of 1 and 2 exhibit the molecular ion [M]+ and the fragmentation pathways occur by cleavage of the metal–ligand bonds. 3.2 X-ray molecular structure of compound 1·HC(pz)3 The crystallographic data are summarized in Table 1 , selected bond lengths and angles in Table 2 and the molecular structure is shown in Fig. 1 . Compound 1 crystallized with one molecule of HC(pz)3 and it presents a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, consisting of the vanadyl oxygen (O1) and the pyrazol nitrogen atom (N31) in the apical positions and the oxygen atoms from acac ligands in the equatorial sites. The binding involves the chelate rings V1On1Cn1Cn3Cn2On2 (n =1 or 2) with bite angles of O11V1O12 88.82(7)° and O21V1O22 89.58(7)°. As expected, the V1O1 bond length, 1.6038(18)Å, is significantly shorter than the remaining VO bond distances; it is longer that those found in [VO(acac)2] [1.561(10)Å] [32a] and [VOCl2{HB(3,5-Me2pz3)}] [1.575(3)]Å) [32b] but shorter than in [VOCl{HB(Me2pz)3}(DMF)] [1.649(5)Å] [32b] and [{VOHB(pz)3}{H2B(pz)2}] [1.607(4)Å] [33]. Furthermore, the VO distances involving the acac ligands, which range from 1.9878(17) to 2.0011(17)Å, are slightly longer than those found for [VO(acac)2] [1.97(1)Å]. The vanadium atom is positioned 0.327Å above the plane defined by the chelating acac oxygen atoms. The VN31 distance of 2.342(2)Å is comparable to those found in other vanadium complexes for which the implicated N-atom is in trans position to the vanadyl oxygen: [VO(acac){HB(pz)3}] [2.338(2)Å] [33], [VOCl2{HB(Me2pz)3}(CH3CN)] [2.368(7)Å] [32], [VOCl2{HB(Me2pz)3} (DMF)] [2.329(6)Å] [32b]. The vanadium complex molecule and the tris(pyrazolyl)methane are strongly associated by means of intermolecular contact distances. Indeed, the molecular structure exhibits the presence of a NH⋯N interaction involving the pyrazol ligand and one of the pirazolyl nitrogens [N32H32A⋯N8: d(D⋯A) 3.043(3)Å, ∠(DHA) 171.1(2)°], and a CH⋯π interaction between the C14H14C methyl moiety and the closest pyrazolyl ring N4N5C4C5C6. The distance between the CH hydrogen and the centroid of this ring is 2.792Å (139.04°), indicating a relatively strong non-covalent interaction. 3.3 Synthesis of 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS membranes and sorption measurements The polymeric membranes based on PDMS were synthesized by crosslinking silanol-terminated PDMS with TEOS in the presence of a Sn-catalyst, with the concomitant addition of the vanadium complexes solution. The overall hydrolysis of TEOS and condensation with PDMS can be written as Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) Si(OCH2CH3)4 +4H2O→Si(OH)4 +CH3CH2OH (2) Si(OH)4 +HO[Si(CH3)2 O] x Si(CH2)OH→ [Si(CH3)2 O]y Si(CH2)O +H2O According to reactions (1) and (2), the number of SiOSi bonds represents the degree of coupling, where y > x [34]. The coupling of TEOS and PDMS, therefore, proceeds through a polycondensation reaction between the terminal silanol groups of PDMS and the OH groups of hydrolyzed TEOS [34,35]. TEOS and silanol-terminated PDMS can react practically with all reactive functional groups, namely the four SiOEt groups in TEOS and two SiOH groups in PDMS, with the formation of ethanol as by-product, on the basis of hydrolysis/condensation reactions. Such reactions and the characterization of membranes based on PDMS have already been described elsewhere [34,35]. In all cases, the vanadium catalyst was the last compound to be added to the mixture. Since the vanadium complexes bearing the pyrazole based groups were soluble in the medium where the membranes were prepared, the occluded V complexes were uniformly dispersed into the PDMS chains, resulting in uniform membranes (Fig. 2 ). The affinity of reagents for the polymeric membrane can be determined by measuring their sorption. The membranes should not restrict strongly the diffusion of small molecules such as cycloalkanes due to their high permeable nature [10]. Their ability to adsorb the oxidants is essential to establish suitable reaction conditions in the catalytic studies. The sorption values for 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS (polymeric PDMS-based membrane with immobilized complex 1 or 2, respectively), after 24h of swelling with the oxidant [m-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (mCPBA), benzoyl peroxide (BPO), hydrogen peroxide, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), or urea-hydrogen peroxide adduct (UHP)], are shown in Fig. 3 . The oxidants have a common peroxo group (OO) and differ on the shape and size of the other attached moieties. The less polar mCPBA and BPO lead to higher sorption values than TBHP, H2O2 or UHP. These results indicate that 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS are typically hydrophobic, with higher affinity for less polar oxidants (mCPBA and BPO) than for more hydrophilic ones (TBHP, H2O2 and UHP). This shows the greater difficulties for TBHP, H2O2 and UHP to enter into the membrane. 3.4 Oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone Complexes 1 and 2, under either heterogeneous (immobilized on a PDMS-based membrane) or homogeneous conditions, act as catalysts or catalyst precursors for the oxygenation of cyclohexane, with any of the above peroxo oxidants, in acetonitrile, to a cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone mixture, usually in acidic medium, at room temperature, according to the overall reaction (3). A high selectivity towards the formation of those products is exhibited by these systems since no traces of by-products were detected by GC analysis of the final reaction mixtures. No cyclohexane oxidation takes place in the absence of the metal complex or the oxidant. (3) The highest catalytic activities are observed under homogeneous conditions, with maximum turnover number (TON, moles products/mol catalyst) and overall yield of 938 (1) or 1.11×103 (2) and 2.0% (1) or 2.4% (2), respectively, in the presence of m-chloroperoxobenzoic acid as oxidant upon 24h reaction time, in acidic medium (Tables 3 and 4 , entry 5). The higher activity of the scorpionate complex 2, relatively to 1, is consistent with the observed behaviour for other C-functionalized scorpionate copper complexes [28]. Although TON values up to 620 could be achieved with the supported catalysts, these are not so active as the homogeneous ones under the same experimental conditions (Tables 3 and 4, entry 5 (S3 and S4)). This is consistent with the natural limitations of the heterogeneous catalytic system, namely the slow diffusion of the reactants to the catalytic and sorption sites. 3.4.1 Effect of type of oxidant and oxidant-to-catalyst amount The increase of the oxidant/catalyst molar ratio results in an enhancement of the TON values for all oxidants studied (Figs. 4 and 5 ). The nature (and the corresponding TON) of the products formed by catalytic oxidation of cyclohexane using 1 and 2 both in the homogeneous and supported forms depend markedly on the oxidant, as shown in Tables 3 and 4, and Figs. 4 and 5. In fact, in our systems, mCPBA behaves as the most effective oxidizing agent among those tested (mCPBA, BPO, TBHP, UHP, H2O2) under both homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions for the cyclohexane oxidation. This behaviour may be account for by the expected strongest oxidizing character of mCPBA [36] and, for the heterogeneous systems, also by its more effective sorption by the membrane (Fig. 3). The appreciable hydrophobic character of mCPBA favours its sorption thus promoting its involvement in the cyclohexane oxidation process catalyzed by the immobilized vanadium complex, as observed in other studies with PDMS-supported catalysts [11,14]. The polar oxidants H2O2, UHP and TBHP were also compared. The TON values obtained with aqueous H2O2 in homogeneous medium were much higher than those of the supported complexes on the polymeric membrane (total TON ca. 410 and 405 for 1 and 2, respectively vs. TON 132 and 40 for 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS, respectively, Tables 3 and 4, entries 15 and 25). In the heterogeneous systems, for TBHP and UHP as oxidants, TONs (and yields) were similar (2-PDMS) to or lower (1-PDMS) than those afforded by aqueous H2O2 (Fig. 5). In general, the lower TONs achieved using the polar peroxides (H2O2, TBHP and UHP) are consistent with the hydrophobicity of the polymeric membrane which hampers their sorption (Fig. 3). In addition, these oxidants may decompose into water (or alcohol, in case of TBHP) and dioxygen, what can be catalyzed by vanadium complexes, similarly to what occurs in the presence of a catalase enzyme [37]. The dismutation of peroxides can also be promoted by the siloxane membrane [37]. 3.4.2 Effect of the amount of nitric acid It is known that the peroxidative oxidation of cyclohexane, catalyzed, e.g., by some iron-chromium hydroxides and hydroxo complexes, or vanadium and copper complexes with N,O-ligands tends to proceed more efficiently in acidic medium [6–8,38]. In our systems, the addition of an acid (HNO3) leads initially to a higher activity (Fig. 6 ). However, for the heterogeneous systems, a further increase of the acid amount (above an acid-to-oxidant molar ratio of 0.25–0.30) results in a lowering of the performance of 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS (Fig. 6), eventually due to the competition between oxidant and additive for the sorption on the membrane. The favourable effect of acid presumably can be associated with the activation of the metal centre by further unsaturation upon ligand protonation, e.g., of the pyrazole or scorpionate ligand (decrease of the hapticity of the latter), the enhancement of oxidative properties of metal complexes, the stabilization of oxidant and promotion of peroxo (or hydroperoxo)-complexes formation [[39] and refs. therein]. However, for the heterogeneous systems, an excess of additives lead to the competition between substrate, oxidant and additive for oxidation at the active site. 3.4.3 Effect of the amount of catalyst and of reaction time A decrease of the catalyst amount leads to a TON enhancement for all the systems, 1, 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS (Fig. 7 , Table S7), as observed in other cases [6e]. For instance, increasing the supported catalyst amount from 0.1 to 0.5μmol results in a TON decrease from 61 to 23, or from 82 to 38, for the 1-PDMS or 2-PDMS catalyst, respectively (Table S8, entries 1–10). Hence, the size of the PDMS membrane is a reaction factor since it determines the catalyst amount. The effect of the reaction time on the activity of 1, 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS in the cyclohexane oxidation was also evaluated (Fig. 8 ). In general, the total TON of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol increased with reaction time, but for both supported catalysts an induction period of ca. 2.5h was observed, possibly associated to the diffusion and sorption of reagents on the membrane. 3.4.4 Mechanistic considerations In order to determinate the type of mechanism of the peroxidative oxidation of cyclohexane, reactions were performed in the presence of radical trapping agents. The oxidation appears to proceed mainly via radical mechanisms involving both carbon-centred radicals (upon homolysis of an alkane C_H bond) and oxygen-centred radicals on account of the pronounced decrease of the catalytic activity (drop up to 95%) for the experiments in the presence of either a carbon radical trap (CBrCl3) or an oxygen radical trap (Ph2NH) [24]. When the oxidation reaction of cyclohexane was performed under the optimized conditions with 2-PDMS, CBrCl3 and BPO, bromocyclohexane and hexachloroethane were detected by GC–MS as the main products. This observation provides strong evidence for the formation of the radical cyclohexyl (Cy) which was trapped by CBrCl3. Thus, in the presence of the carbon radical trap CBrCl3, there is a competition between reaction of Cy with O2 (see below) and bromine atom abstraction (Cy +CBrCl3 →CyBr+ CCl3) [8b,22]. Although the detailed mechanistic pathway is still to be established, peroxo-metal species and hydroxyl HO radical can be derived from oxo-metal-promoted decomposition reactions of oxidant [1a,1c,3d,8,21,22,40,41]. The process could then proceed via formation of the cyclohexyl radical (Cy) upon H-abstraction from cyclohexane (CyH), which undergoes fast oxidation by O2 to give the organo-peroxyl radical CyOO and the organo-hydroperoxide CyOOH (e.g., upon hydrogenation of CyOO by H2O2 or HOO). Metal-assisted decomposition of CyOOH can lead to the organo-oxyl CyO and organo-peroxyl CyOO radicals [1c], the latter thus being regenerated. H-abstraction from the alkane by CyO would form the alcohol CyOH and Cy, whereas CyOO could either decompose to the alcohol and the ketone or regenerate CyOOH and Cy upon H-abstraction from CyH, as proposed [1a,3a,42] for some metal-catalyzed alkane oxidations. However, since the reactions were carried out in solution at low temperature, the radical chain mechanism via CyOO +CyH→CyOOH+Cy is not probable [8b]. The alcohol can also be formed from Cy and a metal-hydroperoxide [6d], the latter being derived, e.g., upon H-abstraction from CyH by VIV OO. The participation of the hydroperoxide CyOOH is corroborated for the catalyst 1 and 1-PDMS by the significant increase of the alcohol amount (by 30 and 35%, respectively) with a concomitant decrease of that of the ketone when the final reaction solution, prior to GC analysis, is treated with an excess of PPh3 (method reported by Shul’pin [3d,23a,23b]). For 2 or 2-PDMS, no CyOOH was detected at the end of the experiments probably due to its metal-promoted decomposition to the alcohol and ketone [6f,6k,40,43] along the reaction. 3.5 Recycling In order to evaluate the possible recycling of 1-PDMS and 2-PDMS, after the reaction they were thoroughly washed with NCMe under vigorous stirring and then reused for a new set of cyclohexane oxidation experiments. The catalytic activity of the recycled membranes was much lower than that of the fresh ones and only traces of products were detected, most likely due to the blockage of the active sites, upon adsorption of the reagents on the membrane surface, which were not effectively removed by the membrane washing procedure. To avoid catalyst leaching, the membrane washing requires the use of a polar solvent (NCMe), but such a solvent cannot penetrate into the membrane, thus making the washing insufficient. The activation of the PDMS based membranes is typically a complicated procedure. 4 Conclusions We have found a simple and convenient route for the formation of oxo-vanadium(IV) complexes with a hydroxo-functionalized C-scorpionate or pyrazole ligand directly from commercially available metallic compounds, what has allowed the synthesis of the first vanadium complex bearing tris(pyrazolyl)ethanol, thus contributing towards the still little explored coordination chemistry of vanadium with such types of ligands. We have also opened up the possibility of applying those types of complexes as catalyst precursors for the single-pot peroxidative cyclohexane oxidation to cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone under mild conditions, at room temperature, under both homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions. In the latter case, the use of a polydimethylsiloxane membrane for the heterogenization of the catalyst was shown to be convenient. Various oxidants of different polarities were tested and, in general, the best results were obtained with the less polar ones (mCPBA and BPO) on account of the hydrophobic character of the membrane that favours their sorption. mCPBA was the most effective one (achieving, in a single batch, TONs up to 1100 and 620 under homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions, respectively), what is also consistent with its expected strongest oxidizing character. Although the homogeneous reactions take place faster than the heterogeneous ones and a higher activity is found in the former case, the use of the PDMS-supported catalysts is promising, since it is based on cheap and easily obtained membrane and vanadium(IV) catalysts, involves a simple way to heterogenize the catalyst without its chemical modification, and allows an easy product separation. The hydrophobic membrane plays a role in selecting the oxidant by its polarity and this behaviour can be further explored towards the selective oxidation of mixtures of substrates. coredata.dc:description: The oxovanadium(IV) complexes [VO(acac)2(Hpz)]·HC(pz)3 1·HC(pz)3 (acac=acetylacetonate, Hpz=pyrazole, pz=pyrazolyl) and [VOCl2{HOCH2C(pz)3}] 2 were obtained from reaction of [VO(acac)2] with hydrotris(1-pyrazolyl)methane or of VCl3with 2,2,2-tris(1-pyrazolyl)ethanol. The compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, Far-IR and EPR spectroscopies, FAB or ESI mass-spectrometry and, for 1, by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. 1 and 2 exhibit catalytic activity for the oxidation of cyclohexane to the cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone mixture in homogeneous system (TONs up to 1100) under mild conditions (NCMe, 24h, room temperature) using benzoyl peroxide (BPO), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), m-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (mCPBA), hydrogen peroxide or the urea-hydrogen peroxide adduct (UHP) as oxidants. 1 and 2 were also immobilized on a polydimethylsiloxane membrane (1-PDMS or 2-PDMS) and the systems acted as supported catalysts for the cyclohexane oxidation using the above oxidants (TONs up to 620). The best results were obtained with mCPBA or BPO as oxidant. The effects of various parameters, such as the amount of catalyst, nitric acid, reaction time, type of oxidant and oxidant-to-catalyst molar ratio, were investigated, for both homogeneous and supported systems.

dc:creator.$: Guedes da Silva, M. Fátima C.

coredata.dc:title: Pyrazole or tris(pyrazolyl)ethanol oxo-vanadium(IV) complexes as homogeneous or supported catalysts for oxidation of cyclohexane under mild conditions
